Introduction

Alport syndrome is a genetic disorder that involves type IV collagen, a major structural component of basement membranes in the kidney, cochlea, and eye.  Clinical manifestations include hematuria and progressive renal failure, bilateral sensorineural hearing loss, and anterior lenticonus (lens protrusion).

Pathogenesis and risk factors



Collagen is a fibrous protein composed of 3 polypeptide alpha chains (

figure 1
).  Each alpha chain in type IV collagen is encoded by a different gene.  Although a mutation in any of these genes can cause Alport syndrome, the most common is a mutation in the COL4A5 gene, which is located on the X chromosome and demonstrates an X-linked inheritance pattern.  The other alpha chain genes are located on autosomes, and mutations in these genes can demonstrate an autosomal dominant or recessive inheritance pattern.  These pathogenic variants result in a spectrum of phenotypes that involves the following structures:



  • Kidneys:  Defective type IV collagen results in a thin glomerular basement membrane (GBM) with impaired filtration.  Over time, the membrane thickens and appears lamellated (layered) due to longitudinal splitting of the lamina densa.  This thinning, thickening, splitting, and layering of the GBM is described as a basket-weave appearance on electron microscopy.
  • Cochlea:  Defective type IV collagen in the cochlear basement membrane results in progressive bilateral sensorineural hearing loss, although the exact mechanism is not well understood.
  • Eyes:  Defective type IV collagen results in a thin lens capsule and eventual anterior lenticonus, or conical protrusion of the lens anteriorly.  If present, anterior lenticonus is pathognomonic for Alport syndrome.


A family history of Alport syndrome is the most significant risk factor for the disease.  Male patients with a mutation on the X chromosome usually express the most severe phenotype with rapid disease progression; female carriers can be variably affected.

Clinical presentation



Because the most common genotype is X-linked, Alport syndrome most commonly presents in male patients with affected family members.  The most common initial presentation is asymptomatic microscopic hematuria.  Auditory and ocular manifestations may also be present, as follows:



  • Renal disease:  Typically presents with an incidental finding of microscopic hematuria.  In some cases, microscopic hematuria is found on routine screening due to a family history of the disease.  Over time, patients develop signs of progressive renal disease, including gross hematuria, proteinuria, and hypertension.  Gross hematuria may be episodic and follow upper respiratory tract infections.  Renal failure typically occurs in adolescence or early adulthood but may occur later in female carriers or in those with different genotypes (ie, autosomal mutations).
  • Auditory manifestations:  Initially manifests as bilateral sensorineural hearing loss in the high-frequency range.  Although hearing loss is progressive, complete hearing loss is uncommon.
  • Ocular manifestations:  Include anterior lenticonus, corneal dystrophy, and fleck retinopathy.  Fleck retinopathy is characterized by superficial white or yellow granulations (flecks) in the retina that surrounds the fovea.  Over time, these ocular manifestations can lead to loss of visual acuity.

Diagnosis



In cases of suspected Alport syndrome (eg, family history of disease with the triad of renal, cochlear, and ocular abnormalities), genetic testing or renal biopsy showing longitudinal splitting of the GBM is diagnostic.  Serum creatinine and blood pressure are typically normal at presentation and in early childhood.  Serum C3 levels are normal and distinguish Alport syndrome from other nephritides.

Differential diagnosis



The differential diagnosis for Alport syndrome includes other hereditary nephritides, although the diagnosis is often distinguished by a family history of progressive renal disease and hearing loss.



  • Thin basement membrane nephropathy (benign familial hematuria):  An autosomal dominant genetic disorder involving genes that encode type IV collagen chains.  The disease is characterized by a diffusely thin GBM and microscopic hematuria.  Gross hematuria and hypertension can occur but rarely progress to proteinuria and renal failure.
  • IgA nephropathy:  An autoimmune disease in which circulating immune complexes containing IgA autoantibodies deposit in the glomerular mesangium, causing progressive glomerulonephritis.  Hypertension and proteinuria can occur.

Management and prognosis



Management depends on the severity of the disease but typically involves the following:



  • Renal:  Following initial diagnosis, management involves close surveillance for progressive nephropathy (eg, serial urinalyses, serum creatinine, blood pressure measurements).  ACE inhibitors may slow disease progression by decreasing intraglomerular pressure and should be considered for those who develop proteinuria.  However, the majority of patients develop renal failure by age 40.  Kidney transplantation is performed in these patients, although there is a risk of developing autoantibodies to the normal graft GBM (ie, anti-GBM antibody disease).
  • Auditory:  Audiometry should be performed to detect early sensorineural hearing loss and identify patients who may benefit from hearing aids.
  • Ocular:  Comprehensive ophthalmologic examinations are necessary to identify abnormalities (eg, anterior lenticonus) that require corrective lenses to maintain visual acuity.

Summary
